comment._content: I know the exact spot, 123 years ago!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Not entirely convinced, though more than willing to be! If you compare the buildings in the photo from 1888, they're mainly brick. In the Google Maps image, the buildings are stone built, and the building on the left has a very curvy corner...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 65361386@N05
comment._content: Interesting this - if you search Google Maps for 96 Thomas Street, you get: maps.google.ie/maps?q=96+thomas+street+dublin&hl=en-G... Which looks like it could be the location, albeit heavily re-built. But the lane is called "John Street", not "John's Lane". And the church next door was opened in 1874, predating the photo above. The other reference that thicky gangli flori gives is on the other side of the church and is indeed "John's Lane"... If only I had an 1888 Thom's directory!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Well, funny you should say that! Will try to check in Thoms for 1888, and will report back...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: My vote is for John's Lane, not John's Street. Looking at the OS 25" map, these two streets are labelled John's Lane and John's Street West. By 1888, the Church to the left of Johns Street West (from Thomas Street) was open, so that isn't it. Flipping between the OS25" and the older 6" maps, you can see that the building to the right of John's Lane used to stick out into Thomas Street, as seen in this picture, and the building to the left used to have a right angle on this corner. In the 25", the building to the left has the modern door at an angle on the corner, and the building to the right is in line with it (this is the sacristy of the church, which I think from that webpage above was finished in 1895). So, I'd say this is John's Lane, and that the modern buildings were built between 1888 and whenever the 25" survey happened, generally around 1900. [Edit: 1907 for this sheet]
